reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever played Bhop? Surf? If so this games mechanics will feel Instantly similar too you. This game gives you such a rush jumping around at these amazing speeds. I cant really explain it, its the kind of thing you just need to experience. With multiple diffrent ways to finish each course it gives the game a competitive feel. You'll be trying to shave off those extra seconds to try and reach the top of the leaderboards on your favorite course.

Visualy this game is stunning while the graphics are very minimalistic it is one of few examples of minimalism done very well in a game. The meticulous design of the levels leads to a mechanical and visual masterpiece. Not only will your eyes love this game but your ears will as well, the music is absolutely magnificent, even while failing a course over and over the music will keep you calm and mellow.

I'm not usually a fan of Early Access but the game is so cheap and the devs seem to be very nice so far so I'm glad to support it in such a early state. If you have a few dollars sitting in your steam account I fully recommend getting this game.

Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fjq-ayEg5kc

SinaRun is a racer/platformer in which you run and jump between platforms. I struggled on this and often found myself falling down over and over again. The game has the just one more go" effect which keeps me trying over and over. I enjoyed the level design and colour schemes of the levels. One addition I would love and which would keep me playing the game would be addition of controller support.

Positives:
+ Low price
+ Colours and levels are quite fun.
+ Leaderboards for competitive speed running play
+ Early Access
date:
so there will be much more to improve on
+ Dedicated developer

Negatives:
- No controller support which would really be beneficial to us non keyboard wielding people
- Slight delay or it feels like to me in the jumps.
- Frustrating when falling over and over

I would recommend this to people who are looking for a fun speed running platformer game. If you enjoy being a ninja this is definitely a game for you. For people who are not used to using the keyboard this may be the game to wait on for controller support if ever added

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA really stylish, pared-down bunnyhopping/parkour game. SinaRun reduces the complex mechanics of bhopping/surf mods to the bare essentials without sacrificing the sense of speed and difficulty. This one is more focused on intense, high speed runs with multiple lines than technical parkour obstacle courses. Although your speed is easily maxed out with the benefit of a sprint key, the game uses a unique timed-jump mechanic (length of press controls jump height/distance... kinda like a 3D flappy bird game on speed :P ). This leaves enough fine control to experiment with different lines and keep the skill-cap high enough so you can improve on your records. For this type of game, this is a brilliant compromise because it doesn't sacrifice the speed/flow for the sake of simplicity, and manages to scratch close to the same itch as notorious mods like Quake Defrag and CS surfing without the huge learning curve barrier. Still needs some tuning, bug fixes and more maps but for <3$ it's well worth checking out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SinaRun is the game ive wanted since I bought Boson X on a whim. Everything I loved about Boson X's minimalist design and fast speed, thrilling platform running is included in this game with a more expounded concept. Its a free runner and you arent tethered to the whims of the level, you will practice going one way on a course just to realize its better to start at another area, relentlessly shaving seconds off your time, and of course falling to your death many many times.

Part of the beauty of this game is that most of the levels are relatively short. At first this surprised me, and I had a thought that they were trying to pack less content in the game by making it ruthlessly hard - but you aren't annoyed when you die in this game because you don't ever have a large amount of time invested in a singular run. This lowers the frustration factor of Boson X a very large degree, with the goal being to simply finish as opposed to gathering energy to pass a level.

This game could definitely use alot more levels, a level editor, and competitive online play and races. A level editor would be amazing.

I think that music is a huge factor in games like these, you cant have the level music get boring after listening to it for a few minutes. The music in this game is top notch, very atmospheric tracks that aren't repetitive, annoying, or ill-fitting. They give you a sense of peace. This is a game where they simply have to release the soundtrack as DLC.

I would also like to see more area's represented, and I feel this game is BEGGING for a forest level. I wouldn't mind seeing a few more mechanics like maybe a wallrun, it could also use a button to instantly reset to the beginning as you can get stuck on lower platforms and end up having to kill yourself after thinking that you might be able to find a way back up.

All in all, this game has the potential to be the shining star in the minimalist free-runner genre. At the moment it needs work but is an extremely good buy for the current price. You can tell a developer is smart when they know where to price their game.

9/10

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

BugZy's Review: SinaRun - The best game you'll fail hundreds of times at!

The following is my opinion.

Retry, retry, retry, retry...

SinaRun is a great 3D platformer racing game, where you try to get to the end of the levels in the fastest possible time by using your extroardinarily fast cybernetic legs. The whole game is basically a time trial that is so relentless that if you make a mistake - and trust me, you will make several hundred before completing each level - you'll have to start from the beginning of the level. No checkpoints, no excuses.

The game currently has 17 levels including the tutorial, with the dev's best score displayed for you to try to beat and a leaderboard for your best score to be displayed publicly too. 17 levels may not seem like much for a game, but when you add the time between your fails and the amount of fails you have accrued, it quickly adds up, especially when you are trying to beat everyone's best times!

You will gain some very useful skills whilst playing SinaRun, such as the natural instinct to swiftly reach for the 'R' key if you get stopped or slowed down when missing a jump, or the ability to get used to the control of your character which can be somewhat awkward to get used to, seeming slippery in a sense. This can have a big impact on your experience, but once you get comfortable with it it becomes second nature.

Despite the game's visual theme being minimalism, it has a high level of beauty with the different map colours and particle effects flying fast towards you as you attempt to make it to the end. This, accompanied by the relaxing music that tries to keep you calm every time you fail, creates a very unique atmosphere (in a good way.)

All things considered, the game is a great play if you would like something to play every now and then and don't mind failing a few hundred times and in all fairness, for $3, it's a bargain!

I rate SinaRun 8/10 extremely quick wombats.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SinaRun is a very fast paced jumping platformer where you try to beat levels as fast as possible. Having speedrun Portal 2 for almost 1,000hrs as well as lightly speedrunning Skyrim and Mirror's Edge I thought I’d love this game, but I was very disappointed.
You barely have any control over your character and the turning is almost non-existent. I thought you would be able to strafe using a and d but sadly once you get going you are pretty much committed to going forwards. Trying to control the speed of your character is pretty tough and you get no feel of when you’re landing on platforms which makes timing the next jump difficult, not to mention how quickly to slide off of platforms once you hit them. I tried to fix this issue by attempting to rebind jump to mouse wheel but the game won't let you.
Overall the game is more annoying then fun to be honest, I only managed to complete the tutorial and one main level which I died on around 50 times before finishing. Very disappointing as you need to be able to control your character precisely in order to complete levels effectively and you just don't get that level of character control.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely loving this game and even have it running as I type out this review.

If any of you reading this have a love for Quake jumping or surfing/bhopping in CS then you will feel right at home with this game, and I would consider this to be the main demographic of the buyers, but would also serve as a great introduction to this sub-genre for first-timers.

The soundtrack for this game is absolutely fantastic. It soothes your soul as you approach the 200 deaths mark and allows you to keep on going trying to beat that time!

Another great thing about this game is that you can see the dev's time for each of the levels, which shows you that the dev cares about this game and is pretty damn good at their own game! I can assure you as a new player it will be taking you quite a while before you can beat the dev's time let alone the #1 spot time!

A couple of suggestions I would like to address to the dev:

The game likes to switch from fullscreen back to windowed (an easy way to replicate this is to have it and then press Escape" to bring up the options menu which will put it into a windowed state).

Some keybinding options are not possible for instance binding "Jump" to "Mouse 2". I would love this due to all of the time I've put into KZ in CS where I either long jump with right click or regular jump with scroll down (I appreciate that jump cannot really be bound to scroll down as jumping in this game has a "height on hold" mechanic - although it would be an interesting addition if you did allow jump to be bound to Space/Mouse 2 and also have the possibility for scroll up/down to also be bound for minimum height jumps! Just an idea!)

I've noticed that "crosshair" is a toggleable option in this game. I think it would be fantastic if it is possible to customise this crosshair. Resize/re-shape etc similar to the sort of crosshair customisation you can find in CS:GO.

Another thing I would like to see added is the option for jumping sounds (probably footstep/landing sounds also) and I'm sure any Quake or CS player would also love this to be added. I understand if you wouldn't want to add this to the minimalistic theme of the game
date: however jumping sounds is just so iconic to these games it would be difficult to not suggest.\n\nNow for something you absolutely should NOT add - a replay/ghost replay mechanic of the top times on the leaderboard. It would absolutely destroy the magic of this game
recommended:
figuring out for yourself the most efficient way to set the fastest times with what you have at your disposal.

I would also like to thank Princesseuh for making a serious product and not making this one of those cheap "rage games" that you find a lot of famous YouTubers playing just to overreact and scream at in order to attract views. Thanks for keeping this classy.

Now with all that said and done it's time to try and beat my 13.214 record on Wandered Hideout (watchout Princesseuh I'm coming for you!)

Update: 12.201 record now :) Princesseuh you got some catching up to do :)

P.S. I've already recommended this game to one of my friends :)"

Uhm, okay, yes, here we go. I like writing funny and random reviews, but this is gonna be a serious one. I just feel like I gotta get this out. I'm gonna start with the pro's and the cons.

Pro's:
The levels are beautiful.
The music fits in really well with the game.
it's addicting.
It's calming?

cons:
This is the slipperiest game I have ever played.
it's a f*cking rage fest.
it f*cks with you're audio.
You feel like you don't have any control over you're character.

okay, let's start. first off, this game NEEDS an update. The audio needs to be fixed and the character should be '' a little bit less'' slippery. I know the game wants you to go as fast as possible, but this is insane. you can't stop. Even in the levels where you ARE supposed to go slow. YOU CAN'T STOP. IT'S TO DAMN SLIPPERY. All of the cons just screw the game for me. Am I the only one who has f*cked up audio when I play the game?
And about the pro's: a beautiful world doesn't make a game good. I am trying so hard to like this game, but I just can't. You can buy this game if you want. It's not my money. And it's not a BAD game. Somethings just have to be fixed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

'I wanna be the very best like no one ever was.'
This line really sums up the game for me. If you like the kind of game where you :

1. Play it
2. Get Better
3. Be the best
4. Keep improving
5. Stay the best

Then SinaRun is for you! You can either try to be the best among your friends or try to be the best in the world. In that way, it really makes me think of Trackmania because I feel the same satisfaction you get from beating your friend's time by that hundredth of a second. And that's just one of the best things in life! Also, there's always room for improvement, so it really is a never ending game.

I'm usually not a fan of Early Access games. But in SinaRun's case, all that is needed for you to have fun is already in the game, so it's not like you're buying it now in the hope that it'll be playable in 4 years. And for the price it's at right now, it's just non-sense to not get it.

I mean, come on. 3$ ? Don't buy a drink at Starbucks next time you're going and you're good!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is so hard and so frustrating that I literally only played it for 20mins before having to put it down before I punched something and I don't normally get that frustrated at games.

I feel bad for the developers because the concept is so good and the graphic style is very unique, I just think that the levels could be designed to flow better so you dont have to constantly adjust speed to not miss platforms.

Whilst the news suggests controller support, this is not yet implemented, so my review may change if this makes gameplay easier.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo an hour into the game i like it a lot. The movement was hard to get used to at first, but you soon get used to it. I like the fact that most levels are relatively easy to complete but to get fast times on them takes time and practice. The soundtrack is amazing and is perfect for calming you down after falling off at the last platform. Also the developer joined my friend and I's lobby and talked to us about the game and our opinions. The developer is nice and seems to want to keep updating the game and making it better. So overall I would reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys slightly rage inducing, platforming games and is definitely worth the price.

reviewerDisplayName: The Guy You Know Down The Road
reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game reminds me of a 2D platformer called gravilon, they both have a great minimalistic asthetic and simple platforming. The diffrence between this and gravilon is that this game fixes all the faults gravilon had and added a few more featured that couldn't have worked there. The controls remind me of when I used to surf in source engine games as the controls are lofty and the platforms are Icy. This Isn't a game you play to complete its a game you enjoy, the music fitted every level and its creative. Sure I only have .5 hours in this game while Im writing this review but Ill be glad to play more and get better and this minimalist platformer.

By this statement I am trying to imply that it is a tad difficult to see a medium length in front but so far I love playing the game and hope for more when it fully releases!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has the most simplest mechanics and minimalistic graphics, yet this is one of the most challenging platformer game I've played. I like how this game made it easy to learn how to jump and get through levels, since the training mode lets you go through any selected level and let's you set restore points in case you're not very good at/not used to the game. I also like how if you're the competitive type, you can always try to get in the top of the leaderbaords, and if you succeed in doing so, maybe actually feel good for something you've done in your life for once.

In short, here are the things I liked most:
Amazing soundtrack
Efficient training mode
Pass levels at your own pace
Maximum overdrive while holding shift Overall, I give this game 9/10. The only reason that I rated it as I did is that I can't seem to ever find a multiplayer server, or it may be that I just can't get it to work.

I recommend this if you like going fast or if you simply like jumping a lot. It's a nice game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SinaRun is one amazing Fast-paced parkour/platforming game with truly stuning music and visuals.Since the price was lowered not too long ago and there are 33% off SinaRun coupons flooding Steam at the moment,the game is a must buy.

I loved my 5 hours of gameplay in the bright world of SinaRun.Sadly the lack of levels in the game limited my playtime, of course you can increase your playtime by achievement hunting" which will probably scar you for life.Without the risk of spoiling anything I could just say that I've had 900 deaths trying to get one of the achievements.

Couldn't ask anything more from the visual aspect of SinaRun.The game is beautiful in its own way and it is well appreciated by a gamer imo.I usually avoid bright fast-paced games  because of my sensitive eyes but after playing for 4 hours in a row during nighttime I felt no eye strain at all simular to when I played Race the Sun.

The music is amazing as previously stated and I would love to hear even more of it in the game
date: also a Soundtrack DLC is a must.The only thing that bothered me was the lack of sound effects when steping on something
hoursPlayed: etc...\n\nThe single player provides you with a basic tutorial and 16 levels all of which have different paths that you can take on the way to the top of the leaderboard.Simple as that
voteText: executed perfectly !\n\nI never played the multiplayer since it's work in progress but I would love to see competitive multyplayer with bunch of gamemodes
helpfulPercent:
dedicated servers and a lot of replayability in the future.

The settings were enough for me.No issues there at all except maybe the lack of full controller compatibility which is not that big of a deal.The game plays perfectly with keyboard and mouse.

After playing the game I wanted to make the level 5 badge but i was put off by the samey badges and not so great emoticons or backgrounds.

Overall I really had fun playing SinaRun.It was different experience and I loved it.The game is definitely worth its price and since it's in Early Access I expect many big and great updates. 9/10"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAmazing game. Im not sure why i got this but it looked good, its a grade a game. Amazing atmosphere, amazing gameplay and amazing concept. A bit hard at first but once you get used to it, youll fly it, 10/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is super simple yet so cool to play. You can play multiplayer. Just recommend adding strafe so the jumps are easier. New levels will come as long as they keep on developing the game. And sure as hell would be cool if jumping was just a matter of holdin the space bar. These are the two concerns I have 1) TURNING (that can be solved by adding the ability to strafe just like in cs 1.6) 2. JUMPING (could use automatic jumping or just some sort of a bunny hop script because pressing SPACE BAR gets annoying after while). Other then these I think the game is tottaly worth the price and should be supperted by purchase and maybe even a little donation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is just...well I didn't like it.  I understand what it's supposed to be: a speedrunning first person platformer, but something about it is just...off.  I think the best way to describe is that it feels like your character has no weight.  It takes a long time to get used to if/when you land on a platform because there's no audio or visual cue that you've landed.  This leads to a lot of frustration as it's hard to learn to gauge jumping and landing,  This wouldn't be a problem if the entire game wasn't centered around jumping onto small platforms at breakneck speed.

4/10
voteText: No ratings yet
